values:
My 2 summoner spells, which I go with almost exclusively are
[spell=exhaust][spell=teleport]
The reasoning: Early game, when mocking shout is more of an inconvenience slow, this will let you keep champions in range for you to finish. It also heavily debuffs damage of both AP and AD champions now, which can also be critical in the under-6 part of the game. Teleport is obviously excellent for almost any champion, and while late game Trynd gets a nice bit of speed from Phantom Dancers, early game you want to be able to spend as much time in lane as possible farming so that you can right click to win later. Also, while not ideal, teleport can be used to escape ganks faster than recalling in a bush.  Since in the latest update of the guide, I change the focus to solo top, the Teleport can let you get a quick edge on your opponent by going back to buy with a minimum of lane time lost.

Other good choices
[spell=cleanse]
One of the ways in which many enemys will finish off a Tryndamere is by CCing him near the end of Undying Rage. This is one of the 2 most common ways you will die as Tryndamere (the other being DOT effects/champions). However, I prefer the Quicksilver Sash if this is a problem you're facing. Not only is it BETTER than cleanse (it removes DoTs and other debuffs, not just CC), but it's very affordable, on a fairly short CD, and gives you some MR which will give you more time to wail on their team before having to rage and GTFO.

[spell=ignite]
Similar to Exhaust, this can help you get some early game kills. I've had Taric's escape by the skin of their stun with just barely over a heals worth of HP in an early bush fight, and ignite would have taken care of that. However, I tend not to take it because late game, Trynd will carve through HP like butter anyway. If you know the enemy team has a lot of healing/lifesteal, this may still be a better choice than exhaust, but in solo normal, I always go exhaust.

[spell=flash]
Another escape/closer. Pretty redundant in my opinion with Spinning Slash, but I suppose you could justify it as anything that keeps you from dying is good. As a couple of comments have mentioned low level dives with Flash can give you some early levels, and flash is never a bad choice.

[spell=ghost] is probably one of the overall best summoner spells in the game, with a significant move speed buff that lasts for a pretty decent length of time. Good for chasing, running away, getting to a team fight, pretty much any time you want to move faster. However, with Phantom Dancers, Trynd will already outrun most champions most of the time, and once he gets in shout range, very few champions will ever escape.

Poor spell choices

[spell=revive]
The usual reason: Dying is something to be avoided.

[spell=heal]
Trynd's own self healing should be more than sufficient for keeping you alive outside of team fights, and heal wouldn't save you in a team fight.

[spell=clarity]
The worst possible spell for Tryndamere. You don't have mana.

[spell=surge]
Surge is one of the new spells, replacing Rally.  It's an attack speed buff for Trynd, but not worth taking. The main users of this spell are AP/AS hybrids like Kayle.

[spell=Clairvoyance]
A great spell, but better taken by a more support oriented character.

[spell=smite]
Used by junglers. While Trynd can jungle, this guide is more about laning as Tryndamere, though I will add a jungling section later when I've had time to experiment and practice a jungle build.

[spell=promote]
I can't say I've gotten much use out of this on any champion I play,, and Trynd doesn't need a minions help farming


[rune=Greater Mark of Desolation]x9
[rune=Greater Seal of Malice]x9
[rune=Greater Glyph of Malice]x9
[rune=Greater Quintessence of Malice]x3
This will give you +12% crit starting, and 15 ArP.

Mastery I go 21/0/9, but that last p
oint in utility is pretty flexible (Ie, if you want to go 22/0/8).  The talents to take in Offense should be clear. I skipped Demolitionist (Trynd is already a great tower destroyer), and the lifesteal talent (because my build includes it already, and I valued getting Quickness in Utility).  As mentioned, the last point in utility can be placed almost anywhere.  Prior to the 11/29/2011 patch, I was using it for extended monster buffs, but you could make an case for Greed, the ward radius talent, quicker recalls, or one last point in Offense.

I've started assembling my crit dmg rune set, but it's very expensive.  I haven't yet gotten to test how the sacrifice of early game crit trades off against end game damage.


For Solo Top:
I have returned to generally starting with a [item=Vampiric Scepter].  As I have shifted to a mainly solo top role, I frequently oppose champs against whom I can maintain regular harass and farm.  I would still consider starting with a rejuv bead for a lane in which I would need to hug the tower for a few levels.  The build is still functionally the same as a duo lane, with a couple major notes:  Consider going for an [item=Executioner's Calling] especially if the lane opponent has a strong heal/sustain mechanic, if there are no other AD to benefit from the eventual Stark's, or if the enemy has strong support healers (Soraka, Sona,etc). 

When solo top, I try and head back around 500 gold (depending on how the lane is going).  Knowing that I'm goingback, I play my first few levels very aggressively.  On my return, I complete the [item=Emblem of Valour] and buy the [item=Vision ward]. Why a pink ward, you ask?  Well, assuming the enemy solo has warded, you'll get back 25 of the gold by killing their ward, and deny them sight that protects them from ganks. Also helpful if facing a Twitch or Evelynn, rare as that is.  Now, you're going to stay in line for a while.  You want to be able to purchase at least [item=Berserker's Greaves] and the +crit item for your [item=Zeal].  The trip after that complete Zeal,and get either a BF Sword (if you can afford it) or more likely a [item=Cloak of Agility]. From here, complete the [item=Infinity Edge] as soon as you can afford.

For Duo Bottom
Personally, I like to start with a [item=Rejuvenation Bead]. I used to start with [item=Vampiric Scepter], but frequently, I found going against ranged harassers would deny me the ability to actually hit minions for getting your life back. With the Rejuv bead, you can hold up at the tower and still recover health. Once you have 550 gold, recall and get [item=Emblem of Valour] and then teleport back to the lane. You lose almost no time thanks to teleport, and now you and your lane partner have a pretty decent amount of health regen+your own lifesteal. Your 2nd rank of Bloodlust should be coming in by now too. Once you hit 5 and your 3rd rank, Bloodlust+[item=Emblem of Valour] should make you extremely difficult to harass, barring certain enemy champion combination's. Now, you should be able to farm contentedly for a while. Stay in until you have a decent chunk of gold. Note, that is is EXTREMELY important for you to use some of your own judgment here. Remember that you do not have boots at this point, which can put you at a real disadvantage. Ideally, you'll reach over 1k gold by the time your teleport is up again, in which case, feel free to make use of it to retrieve your [item=Berserker's Greaves], or just the [item=Boots of Speed] if you can't afford them by the time you're back. However, if you don't need the speed (for example, you are already faster than your opponents, or your lane partner has powerful slows or taunts), feel free to hang out as long as you feel you can afford to operate without boots. If the enemy is particularly stun or immobilize heavy (particularly if they are also AP heavy), [item=Mercury Treads] may be a better choice than Berserker's, but your DPS will be noticeably less for it.

Once you have your T2 boots, the next item on your agenda is a [item=Zeal], or at the very least it's components ([item=Brawler's Gloves] first if you must choose]). Zeal is an amazing item, it speeds up your attack speed (more attacks = more chances to crit), gives you crit, and perhaps most importantly, gives you move speed. Should bring you to about 420 move, which should be plenty for the time being. Next, we start on the item which is the very soul of a Tryndamere, the [item=Infinity Edge].

It is EXTRAORDINARILY unlikely that you can just buy the entire IE at once. I almost always start with [item=Cloak of Agility] which brings your crit to about 42% at 100% HP. Whether you get the [item=Pickaxe] or [item=B. F. Sword] next is largely up to you. The Pickaxe costs half of what the BF sword does for half the damage it gives, so the order is pretty unimportant. I'd go with the BF if possible, but if team fights have already started at this point, you made need the smaller damage boost earlier. Either way, you're getting both and then finishing the IE.


Post Laning Phase
It is around this point that the game starts to belong to you. Next, we upgrade [item=Zeal] into [item=Phantom Dancer] or start [item=Phage]. Phage is great is the enemy is particularly kite-oriented or is frequently fleeing, and also gives us a bit extra HP. This boosts our move to a very respectable 442, and makes us swing like a crazy dude, crit'ing virtually every swing. Note that if a particular champion has been a problem for your team, now is the time you begin to counter build them.

At this point, you are completely ready to dominate the game, if you haven't already. You can carve through squishy's in probably 2 seconds flat, and even tanks can't ignore you for long. It's up to you to decide whether to complete the [item=Frozen Mallet] or [item=Phantom Dancer] first, but both are core in all but the most unusual cases. So what items you build next is somewhat up to you. Here are some common choices for me below:

[item=Stark's Fervor] Stark's is pretty much one of the best items in the game. You already have the Emblem of Valour from early laning phase, so all you need is another 1750 and you get a lifesteal and attack speed aura for your team, and an armor debuffing aura that affects your enemies. Pretty much the only time this is not incredibly awesome is if someone else on your team has built it already, it sort loses some of the appeal. However, I often wait to build this till after I complete Phantom Dancers, IE, and depending on the flow of the game, a defensive item or two.

[item=The Black Cleaver] or [item=Last Whisper] Enemy tanks are likely to have good armor, and tanky DPS are as well. Depending on which is being more of a problem, take one of these. Both give good AD, and the cleaver boosts your AS even more (though it costs about 1k gold more too).  Frankly, I almost never get the Cleaver.  With the new Mastery's, Last Whisper makes for a 46% ArP. Only a pure armor build can really stand up to that, and that's why you have AP teammates.  LW has practically become core in any game in which enemy team members purchase armor items for me.

[item=Sword of the Occult] Always fun when you're dominating a game. However, I can't recall having gotten this item since hitting Summoner L20. I'm going to go with almost 100% of the time, you are better off with a defensive item in your 5th and 6th slows, or a hybrid item like Frozen Mallet, or something like a Bloodthirster to give you a nice Lifesteal chunk with your AD. Frankly, I can't think of a time I've used this in a real game as Tryndamere.

[item=Quicksilver Sash]A personal favorite of mine for MR, this item is great for when the enemy team tries to keep you there with only a second left on UR. Also great for: Ruining the day of any Malzahar, Vlad, or Warwick who ults you. Nothing like watching their ult dissipate in the press of a button right before you cut them in half to give you that "Pwned, noob" feeling.

[item=Guardian Angel]Do you want to frustrate the hell out of the enemy team? GA is for you. Gives some nice all round defensive bonuses, and the getting back up is nice too. Don't rely on using it to rejoin a fight, since you'll probably have burned rage before it activates, but at least they didn't get a kill on you, and you can return in a minute after you go whack a few jungle mobs to heal to full.  I've only done this once as a troll build, with a Zilean and Yorick on my team. 

[item=Force of Nature] or [item=Randuin's Omen] or [item=Thornmail] For teams that are overstacked on one damage type or the other. Thornmail for physical and FoN for magic. FoN has the added bonus of more move speed and a ton of health regen, and a Trynd wearing it is pretty much the terror of the battlefield to any caster. Thornmail is less devastating because melee characters generally try and avoid slugging it out with Trynd to begin with. The FoN combined with a [item=Frozen Mallet] is even better, as it increase Trynd to having near 3k health, improving both the regen effect and giving him a slow on attack.  Randuin's can be a very solid choice (it slows people attacking you and gives you a second AOE slow as it's active), and the HoG component will mitigate the cost somewhat. 

[item=Bloodthirster] is on it's face a great item.  Unfortunetly, you'll usually have to either get armor pen or defensive items or utility in your last 2 slots, and if you need none by the time you can afford this, you're already winning too hard anyway.


Certain champions are particularly easy or difficult for Tryndamere at various phases of the game, and certain champions are very dangerous when paired with certain partners or types of partners.

Teemo
Teemo gets first mention because I hate him. I hate his stupid adorable face, and I want him to report for execution, not for duty. I hate his stupid mushrooms in the bushes in the jungle, and I hate when his poison outlasts UR and finishes me after I leave a fight, and I hate when he used to be able to blind-exhaust-blind me. Fortunately for me, Teemo is squishy. REALLY squishy. Unfortunately, he's also really good at running away. If he's harassing you early in your lane, whirling to him and smacking him a few times is usually a good way to discourage him, but...

By around L5-6, your healing should pretty much outdamage his harass. Most Teemo's nowaday seem to go AP/AS, so if there's a powerful AP carry, that FoN you should be getting will mitigate him as well. But he's still worth bewaring.

Teemo/CC partner
This is where Teemo becomes a real danger to Trynd. With a stun, taunt, or immobilize capable partner, Teemo becomes fairly safe from counter attack by a solo Tryndamere. A stun on Trynd after he's whirled to Teemo is likely to be fatal for Trynd, or at the least, force a rage. At this point, you may be best off retreating to your tower until your lane partner or jungle can assist you in killing the damn munchkin.

Lee Sin, the Blind Monk
Whoa boy. Lee Sin is a pretty hard counter for Trynd. He slows your attack speed with Cripple, gains armor and lifesteal from his shield, and most of the successful builds I've seen have been fairly tanky. Oh, and he can chase pretty well by combining Safeguard and Sonic Wave. His ult also deals a pretty big burst compared to his other moves and can take you offguard. It also lets him get away pretty effectively if you're beating him in a fight. If you can make him miss you with Tempest though, you've got the edge.  Lee Sin is often played as a jungle now.  If you dodge his Q, you can usually escape him easily when he ganks.

Caitlyn
If Caitlyn starts in your lane, she's actually not that bad. She can harass you, but if your partner is helping you control the bush, it's not too bad. Where Caitlyn becomes a real problem for Trynd is if she starts mid and then leaves mid to harass other lanes (which puts her damage generally above your ability to heal). She is difficult to 1 v 1 for Trynd in a lane because of her ability to control the bushes with her traps and range. Her sniper shot can (and usually will) strike after Rage ends, resulting in your unfortunate demise.

Stealth Champions
Other than the usual oracles/vision wards solutions, Trynd has a special advantage in detecting stealthed champions. If Mocking Shout is useable, but there's no one visible around, there is a stealther near you (also useful for bush checking!). Retreat to a tower, or at least get some help, a gank is probably coming your way. Akali's smokebomb is also a real pain for Trynd, but when trying to outlast it, just head for the nearest bunch of minions and start carving em up for health. This will matter less after the stealth rework, but that's not in yet.

Galio
It used to be that Galio's ult basically amounted to suicide if he caught Tryndamere in it, because a Tryndamere, combined with the rest of his team, would often kill the Galio before the ult ended, accomplishing little. Now that his ult has built in damage reduction, try and stay spread out. Your still likely to be the 'target' of the ult, but try not to let him take your AP teammates with you.

Fiddlesticks
Don't panic when he starts fearing and draining you. As long as you've gotten your IE, you can cut him down faster than he can probably drain you and his silence won't do shit to help him. And when he gets you low, rage and just take his face off. That being said, I hate Fiddle almost as much as Teemo and I often get an Executioners Calling just for him (and the lifesteal+crit isn't bad). If he gets the drop on your team with crowstorm, focus him. Your ult will buy you the time to at least remove him from the field, and you may even live afterwords to enjoy it.

Udyr
Ugh. Udyr is one of the most frustrating champions in the game for Tryndamere (and I think everyone else), just because he runs super fast with his turtle shield on, and then when you get to him, he stuns you and runs off again. Frozen Mallet or help from your teammates is really all you can do to kill him.   He is extremely dangerous to solo top Tryndamere.  If you don't have good awareness of your minimap (or didn't ward), he can come out of the jungle and stun you very quickly, before you can fall back to your turret.  Beware the Udyr jungle.  BEWARE

Rammus
If you need to kill a Rammus, wait for his Defensive Curl to go off. Rammus is actually surprisingly squishy when that isn't on, and hitting him while it is is likely to do next to nothing (and it has a damage return). If a Rammus is pursing you, try and run him into minion lines. In the jungle, consider whacking a camp mob so that they follow you and crowd the already narrow path in the jungle for him to run into. Try and fight near minions, every Rammus ever has Sunfire and will draw some aggro from minions and you will have a convenient source to hit for lifestealing your health back to survive tremors.

Yi
Free kill, 1 v 1, unless Yi realizes this in time to pop his ultimate and run away. Yi's should never engage a Tryndamere alone unless fed to godly levels. The only real other danger I can see is the AP Yi build might surprise burst a Trynd before he ults, but you can see the Alpha Strike coming, so shouldn't really occur.

Jax
Pre Phantom Dancer nerf, my advice was Do Not Confront. Now, they have more manageable dodge, but you may want to consider a sword of the occult anyway if they're doing well. Do not stand toe to toe with a Jax. Jax gains a stacking attack speed buff, so when fighting him, whack him a few times, and then run off until you see the buff dissipate off him, then re-engage. Smart Jax's will keep this up by hitting your minions, try not to fight him near them (this is doubly true, as they will attack him, miss, and give him more dodge/stuns). Even if fed well above Jax, do not underestimate him, he can ruin your day.  They are apparently planning to remove Dodge from the game, this may bring swift justice to Jax players.

Singed
Another champion with an annoying ability to run away, if you don't catch him almost immedialty during pursuit, back off. You are chasing through a poison cloud (if the Singed is even halfway competent) and when you are low enough, Singed will turn around, throw you, and then spray goo on you to slow you. As mentioned earlier however, Singed can be a great laning partner for early game kills. A FoN+Frozen Mallet can be an effective counter to his strategy, but still, you're usually better off doing something else.

Pantheon
Pantheon has been at various points kinda scary. Since his stun length and burst damage was nerfed, he is now actually kind of squishy, and nowhere near as dangerous. The key is to remember that your first hit will always be blocked, and to walk around his Heartseeker strike (in other words, don't stand in the spears).

Sona/Taric/Soraka
Generally, you will be able to outdamage the healer as long as you can sustain damage on the target (meaning they don't stun you). However, I prefer to just kill the healer whenever possible. Taric is particularly vicious with a ranged harasser in early game however, as he can stun you in place when you whirl in and then shatter to lower your armor while the ranged (or just his minons) tears you up.

Taric also gets special mention as a good support duo bottom.  His shatter let's Tryndamere tear foes apart, especially combined with Dazzle for a stun.

Karthus
Karthus is pretty easy to kill (Though he'll remain in the fight for 8 more seconds after that), but the reason he's getting a mention is his ult. Karthus's LOVE to use their ult to finish a Tryndamere who has escaped and whose rage has worn off. I STRONGLY reccomend MR against a Karthus. Even if you just buy a [item=Negatron cloak] and nothing else. On most champions I would say a BV, but the lack of mana on Trynd makes that suboptimal. Here's a fun fact though: Quicksilver Sash cleanses Karthus's ult. That's right, his ult is like Vlad's on a global scale in that there's a debuff that triggers the damage at the end. Pop... no ult.

Edit: This is no longer the case for Karthus's ult.

Nocturne
Nocturne is one of the newer champions, and a personal favorite of mine when I play to play a ganking assassin. His only real danger to Tryndamere is if you're at low life and you see Paranoia (Nocturne's Ultimate) go up, you may want to consider a pre-emptive rage. If you think you can survive it, feel free to just wait for him to show up. A lot of Nocturne's power comes from his ArP combined with the panic that losing sight of everything on the map causes, but in a straight up slugging match, he should be no match for Trynd. If you dodge his Q attack (the claw thing), he's pretty much screwed, as it is a major damage source for him. Oh, and his fear is a bitch too, but no more than anyone else with a 2 second CC.

Vayne
Fuck Vayne. I don't think anyone else as bad to go against as Vayne for Tryndamere. She can rapidly attack, close, and retreat, deals lots of burst, and can knock you away, stun, and escape with easy. She gets faster when she chases so if you move to engage, you pretty much have to committ, because running will kill you. This is where having a stunner is essential, because a decent Vayne will roll around you, shoot you into a wall and stun you, and you'll be half dead and she'll be halfway up the lane before you catch up.

Riven
A skilled Riven can be a major threat, particularly in Dominion.  Try and juke her stun (ie, run in close, and immediatly back off, the range is very short), because if you manage this, you will probably have her.  She can't usually win a straight slug fest with Trynd, but she usually doesn't have to.  Her high mobility let's her escape easily even when slowed.  In Dominion, where she doesn't really need to farm, she is much worse, as farming is probably her main weak point.

Wukong
Wukongs main threats come from his ult, and his ability to harass in lane. Counter his use of decoy with a pink ward in the lane, if you have to go up against him.

Fizz
Fizz isn't too scary, at least not for Trynd.  When trying to kill him, be extremely aware of his little pole stand move.  While he's in the middle of it, he will be unaffected by Mocking Shout.

So my birthday is in 4 hours, and I'm not really feeling that great, for two reasons.  One, I'm exhausted from not sleeping much this weekend, and I have a stuffed up nose.  Two, I finally just mustered up the backbone to tell Tennessee Teresa that I don't want to date her anymore.  The long distance thing is not working for me at all, and having a girlfriend I just don't really care about feels wrong on so many levels.  I know I'm making the right decision, I just feel guilty about how heartbroken she is (as well as being somewhat concerned that she'll go and do something stupid).  Right now, she's just trying to cling to the relationship because I think this is the only half-decent relationship she's ever had (and also the first time a guy has broken up with her instead of the other way around).  

Just the more I thought about it, the more I realized that the only area where we really mutually hit off to the same degree was sexually (which I must conceded, we did have excellent compatibility, though I might have preferred if she was more of a sub once subdued).  I mean, we enjoyed some of the same movies and shows, so that wasn't really like terrible incompatibility, but I always felt like we had to struggle when selecting something to watch together.  And our political and religious views are just about as polar opposite as they get.  And there's all these little things, po-tato- po-ta-to kind of stuff that we disagree on, like Marvel vs DC.  Everyone knows Marvel is a way better comic-verse, but she prefers DC.  By itself that's not a big deal (or even anything other than a "eh, why?"), but there's all kinds of little stuff like that.  And it's not like she did anything wrong, she just... didn't do all the right things.  I wanted so bad to get her into some of the games me and my friends played, the way most of my ex's have been, but she only maintained interested as long as I sat her in my lap and was like "PLAY, WOMAN!"  Megan for example, got so into Dragon Age that she actually quit when she foudn out she was gonna have to choose between herself or her in-game romance dying or her in-game romance sleeping with Morrigan, because she was so upset at the idea of having to make that choice.  I love that she empath'd with her game character to that degree (and that since we talked about DA:O recently, she's been playing it frequently.  I think she has 3 play throughs going).  Even Jo used to be more fun than and put more effort into playing with me than Teresa did.  Well, rather, Teresa put in the effort to try, but I knew she was only playing to try and please me.
Well, while Thursday night might have sucked pretty hard, the rest of my weekend was absolutely amazing.  To be updated later when I'm not watching Red Cliff with my friends.

I know that if you were just reading this journal to get a viewpoint on my life, this entry may leave you feeling like you missed a lot.  You did.  I'm not here to talk about all the things that happened since my last entry, I'm here to talk about what happened last night.

Around 9:38 pm, right before the pull in which we killed Heroic-mode Dreamwalker in ICC (or healed her, or however you want to phrase it), I was glancing at my Steam friends list and realized Megan wasn't anywhere on it.  To confirm I wasn't just somehow missing something I ran to Facebook to check, and sure enough she had de-friended me there as well.  I  quickly sent her a "Hey!" text and attempted to call her, which I got immediately directed to voice mail.  I told Dan about it, and then told Aaryndon that if possible, I wanted to be swapped out because something had come up that wasn't strictly an emergency, but that I wanted to take care of right away.  While we're in mid Dreamwalker pull, I get a long text which opens with her saying she decided that she isn't ready to be friends with me, and the part that I really think upset me where she said I was a poison sapping her personality and causing her stress.  I was becoming increasingly stressed myself the more I read this and thought about it.  And while Sindragosa normal mode went smoothly (as well it should by this point), Lich King was a disaster.  THREE out of the four times I got targeted with defile, I dropped it practically in the middle of the raid.  Rightfully so, Don was furious with me, and I was furious at myself.  If I had been raid lead, I would have kicked me out after the 2nd time, and the third would have had me screaming my head off.  We didn't kill him last night, though we were close several times and I completely blame myself for this.  Teresa (Dan and Aura's friend from Tennesse) and Dan tried to cheer me up, and while they succeeded in taking my mind off things for a little bit, I woke up this morning unable to think about anything but being told I was poison by a girl that I have spent over three years of my life with.  And it's like a slideshow of happy memories won't stop playing in my head now, where I can so clearly recall staggering off the train at Hull station and her running to me, and how happy she was to see me, and then staggering through Hull (and nearly getting run over by a bus) to collapse on her cot of a bed and sleep for like near eighteen hours.  Or how she used to be fun and laugh and actually be pleasant to be around, instead of this stern, disapproving, shrew of a woman that she is now, where every little thing pisses her off to no end and she spends all her time hating things and disliking things and complaining about this and that.  Right after we broke up, I thought the change was my fault, and in a way I still think it is.  But more likely than me sucking out all the sunshine and replacing it with venom, I think more likely is that the sunshine was just the outer coating and all that venom was already in her from her being unhappy pretty much her entire grade school life (much as the venom in me comes from my younger years, and Joanna just helped me learn to spit it).  

So now I guess we'll see what happens.  I REALLY wish she had waited like two more days to decide this, so that she could have been there for the boss fight in D&D against the quori... I'm still not sure that thing won't stomp the party into the ground, even with the ludicrously healing twinked cleric that Robert is putting together for that new guy.  If it works as he says, he can do a 13 HP heal EVERY ROUND, which is crazy.

So still haven't picked up a new job yet.  I think it's because I keep limiting myself to places I WANT to work rather than just any place that will hire me.  Unsurprisingly, most of the places I want to work are fairly hotly contested.

Entertainment news: I don't think I've mentioned my return to the EVE life, which I'd rate as a success thus far. Megan finished construction on my Abaddon battleship and I've been doing L4 missions ever since. Eberron Campaign Timeline

8 Nymm, 998 YK: Game begins. The Forgotten Forge is run. All warforged involved are slain, and only one final messenger escapes.

12 Nymm: Festival of Brightblade in Sharn. Caena participates in the various tournaments, reaching the second round in both dueling competitions, but being soundly defeated in archery and the grand Melee. Sarge intimidates a crowd of shifters into sitting quietly. Maximillian assists House Jorasco healers throughout the tournament.

13 Nymm: Party joins the Clifftop Adventurer guild. Receives their first assignment as a contract from a prefect of Morgrave University to locate Demisi and find out why she has not returned. Party manages to successfully locate her at the Medusa’s Kiss, and after a brief verbal confrontation, withdraws, having fulfilled the technical terms of their assignment.

14 Nymm: Maximillian receives a message from Elaydren d’Cannith and the party is hired to find the Whitehearth facility. Shadows of the Last War begins. The party initially plans to simply turn the letter and information over to a person they believe to be a House Cannith contact and wash their hands of the matter.

15 Nymm: Party departs Sharn via Lyrander Elemental Galleon.

18 Nymm: The party defends the Galleon Lightning on the Water from a raid of skeletons. The captain Vennet d’Lyrannder writes them a commendation, believing the raid to be from Karnathi or Lhaazarian pirates.

20 Nymm: The party arrives at Rhuukan Draal, and locates Falian. They discover he has no affiliation with House Cannith, but eventually decide to carry through the contract. After saving Falian from bugbears, he takes them to Rose Quarry, where they unsuccessfully attempt to sneak into the town. They fled the ruins of the quarry, after killing Kaela and one of the other guards.

21 Nymm: The party observes guards on patrol throughout the day. They sneak back into the Quarry at night and find the place largely deserted. After locating the hidden Cannith facilities, they are ambushed by the remaining Emerald Claw forces. Surprisingly, they defeat the Emerald Claw forces, and capture Keltis Doran. Mallora and the rest of the soldiers are killed, and Garrow flees invisibly, watching the party via his undead vulture.

22 Nymm: The party returns to Rhuukan Draal, selling off most of their loot from Rose Quarry and auctioning off Keltis Doran to a hobgoblin with a wide grin.

24 Nymm: The party finishes crafting some magical items in preparation for their trip into the Mournlands. They purchase horses and set out.

25 Nymm: Party arrives at Whitehearth after avoiding some skeletal wolves and defeating a young injured carrion crab. Exploring the place, they befriend the awakened wolf pack and it’s dire wolf leader, Rorsa. They assist Rorsa in freeing the remaining wolves who have been trapped in a cages since the Mourning from a half-golem wolf. After further exploration of the facility, they located two copies of the schema. Garrow ambushed them, and demanded the schema. Seth immediately handed over one of the schema that they’d found. Garrow left, taking their horses with him. The party begins walking out of the Mournland, which occurs without incident other than a brief encounter with some air elementals.

26 Nymm: The party reaches Gorgonhold outside the Mournland and buys horses from a rather questionable middle aged human who works the stables. They begin riding back to Rhuukan Draal.

5 Lharvion: The party reaches Rhuukan Draal. Early in the morning about a day’s walk from the city, they abandon their horses, having noticed two hobgoblin’s in unknown uniforms shadowing them for the past several days. Seth leaves about 20 gold in these horses saddlebags, suspecting that these hobgoblins are pursuing the horses. The party rests in the Guardian’s Gate Inn, the most secure inn in the city.

6 Lharvion: The party goes downstairs to find Elaydren d’Cannith waiting for them. She pays them for their work in retrieving the schema and offers to pay them an additional thousand each to escort her back to Sharn via the Lightning on the Water. Captain Vennet recognizes the party when they board, which they do immediately at Seth’s insistence. Seth also then sells the creation pattern that they discovered to Elaydren for another thousand gold a piece, as it’s recovery wasn’t part of their original contract.

7 Lharvion: The party members notice four black cloaked figures watching the Lightning on the Water, as it emerges from the river into the ocean, but they take no action.

11 Lharvion: The party arrives at Sharn without incident, and proceeds to accumulate a great deal of wealth through both their contracted payments from Elaydren and the sale of a great deal of equipment. Seth goes to work crafting magical items and the like for the rest of the party.

15 Lharvion: Paladin Alexander Taggert kills an evil necromancer in northern Karnath while on a mission for the Lightbringers, a largely Flamite organization which is dedicated to the eradication of undead. With his dying breath, the necromancer places a wasting curse on the Paladin, the Curse of the Decaying Raven.

17 Lharvion: Alexander finds the curse extremely resistant to all attempts to break it through conventional means. He seeks aid in divining a way to break the curse from the main body of the Lightbringers.

20 Lharvion: The party mostly relaxes and enjoys their newfound wealth while Seth works on items from his barracks spot in the Clifftop Adventurer’s Guild hall. Maximillian visits with Naz’ghuul, his mentor about his return to his homeland of Cyre. He learns from Naz’ghuul the planned beast for the Festival of the Hunt this year is a Displacer Beast. By the end of the day, Seth has finished up his item crafting. Whisper of the Vampire’s Blade begins. Lucan Stellos, an elite agent of the Dark Lanterns, traces Calderus to her lair as he investigates her spy network, and is turned into a vampire.

21 Lharvion: In the pre-dawn hours, Lucan Stellos breaks into one of the vaults of the Dark Lanterns under Calderus’s orders to steal a magical longsword known as the soul blade. He kills or incapacitates the guards, and flees the city with his sister on a carriage, heading for Trolanport. Around ten o’clock in the morning, a House Orien courier arrives for Maximillian with a letter requesting his presence and that of his trusted friends. The Dark Lanterns have taken note of their accomplishments in the Mournland and want to use proxy agents to recapture Lucan. After an audition involving the defeat of a dire ape without killing it, they are given their mission details and sent after Lucian immediately.

4 Barrakas: Festival of the Hunt in Sharn. The party catches up with Lucan Stellos and his sister in the evening, a little before sunset, and engage him. They disable Lucan’s carriage and he and his sister flee invisibly shortly before it crashes. The party rides the rest of the night and reaches Trolamport. Sarge spends the night roaming the city looking for information on what a ‘krell’ mentioned in Lucan’s notes might be, and finds little but sahguain muggers.

5 Barrakas: The party spreads out again seeking information on what a ‘krell’ might be, and come up with the name “Neya ir’Krell”, an Aundarian diplomat. The party goes to the Aundarian embassy to speak with her, but are refused admittance. Seth leaves her with a message about Lucan possibly being after her life. Aware that she will be at the ball that evening, Maximillian goes to the House Orien enclave in the city and manages to pick up a date for the ball, thus securing for himself an invitation. Caena attempts to find work as a servant, but Aundarians are not notorious for hiring Valenar elves as servants to high security, invitation-only, balls a few hours before they occur, especially when they show up with no references, in singed travel clothes with a battle mask on. Meanwhile, Maximillian picks out an outfit for himself, in indigo blue with Cyran purple, and buttons that combine the crest of House Orien with the symbols of Cyre, and the whole thing with a great deal of silver trim. He also had a blue and purple mask with a silver rim. When Caena and Maximillian return to the inn to discuss plans with Seth and Sarge, a Orien courier arrives with a letter to Seth. The letter indicates that Neya has received his message, and that she would be interested in discussing the matter at the ball tonight. It also included four invitations. Seth strongly opposed going, believing it to be a trap. At the others insistence, he finally agrees to wait nearby the embassy with their adventuring equipment at ready, while the rest infiltrate the masquerade. Caena obtains a red and gold outfit similar to the Valenar traditional garb, but with a more ‘high society’ touch than an eye to efficient but glorious combat. Sarge chooses to wear a dress, which makes him/her something of a sight, as warforged in frilly dresses are highly unusual. The three of them spread out through the masquerade, Maximillian being pulled into a number of dances by his date, Kirian Orien. After about twenty minutes, Maximillian manages to locate Neya and begins to speak with her, but in the midst of their conversation, Meena’s attempt to charm person Lucan fails fairly miserably (as it doesn’t work on undead), and he calls forth the soul blade from inside his glove of storing and nearly kills her in his initial attack. The crowds panic, blocking clear shots for the gnome guards. The two Aundairian agents with Meena attack, which results in the first of them being cut clean in two by a blow for Lucan, and the second, who was moving to protect Meena taking a fatal stomach wound. His sister, Grilsha killed two of the Embassay guards with a scroll of lightning bolt in her attempt to both clear a escape route and to kill Neya, who she saw as betraying them. Meena then attempted to entrap Lucan in a web, which he effortlessly evaded. Seth made it inside, using mage hand to get Sarge’s heward’s handy haversack to him and attempted to use a scorching ray against Lucan. Lucan again evaded the attack with ease, however, the ray ignited the webs, which began burning outwards, towards where Sarge, Maximillian, and many of the fleeing party guests were. Maximillian managed to free himself to the degree that he was able to cast create water and douse the fire before it spread too far along the threads. At this time, Lucan decided the odds were getting too far against him, and retreated towards the exit that Grilsha had cleared, and she used a scroll of wall of ice to block off their escape. After Maximillian had been freed from the webs by Sarge, he healed the monk of his otherwise-fatal stomach wounds and patched up Meena. After a few moments conversation, Meena had everyone clear the area around the wall of ice and used her fireball spell to break it down and set off in pursuit down the corridor. The party learned from Neya that Lucan was headed for Karnath by way of an airship docked at the local Lyrander tower. The made their way to the tower, and forced their way past the dominated gnome dockworkers, killing three of them in the process and leaving one to bleed to death. Maximillian stabilized two that were bleeding to death before being pulled onboard the airship. They paid their passage using the letter of credit given to them by Breland, and presented also their recommendation from Captain Vennet.

6 Barrakas: Having settled down on the airship in their two cabins, the party began to discuss ways to find Lucan and Grilsha. Seth declared that he would be scribing scrolls in the morning, and not to disturb him. The rest of the party went to check out the passengers. They didn’t find anyone suspicious, and eventually rested as well. Seth awoke early and began working on scribing a scroll of detect undead. The party spent most of the day on deck. Once Seth completed the scroll, he attempted to use it to sweep the ship for Lucan, but because Lucan was in the dimensional locker, he did not detect his presence anywhere. After this strategy failed, he used a scroll of detect magic and began sweeping the ship with that. Using this strategy they located Grilsha and spoke with her. After negotiation with her, she said she would inform her brother of their desire to meet and retired for the night.

7 Barrakas: The party spent the day in various preparations and enjoying the scenery. That night, when they headed on deck to meet with Grilsha, she informed them that he had agreed to meet them in a few hours. However, just as she told them this, they noticed another airship approaching from below, and several skiffs loaded with Emerald Claw boarders rising up. Caena fired a scorching ray at the pilot of the lead skiff, and it crashed into the side of the Cloud’s Destiny. The rest of the boarding party made it onto the deck, while archers fired from the safety of their skiffs. The party engaged in fierce combat across the deck of the ship. As the crew and Emerald claw casualties mounted, Sarge went below deck to search for Lucan. As she was nearly to his locker, he emerged, killed the Emerald claw search team that had come below deck to look for him, and rose as mist to the deck of the ship. The captain of the Jade’s Fire, the Emerald Claw ship, fearing that he was about to escape, rammed the Cloud’s Destiny. As the ship approached, Seth ran below deck to warn Sarge. The elementals of both ships broke free and engaged in combat. Ironically, the Cloud’s Destiny was powered by a fire elemental and the Jade’s fire by a air elemental. The combat between the two looked as if there was a tornado of fire engulfing the wreckage of the two ships as they plummeted from the sky. Lucan assumed bat form and flew off, and Grilsha cast a spell to do the same. Garrow, disguised as the captain of the Jade’s Fire, drank of potion of fly in order to insure his escape. Maximillian used his dragonmark to teleport onto the remaining skiff with the four surviving archers. Caena had engulfed the ship in a choking smoke with fire spells and a cast of pyrotechnics earlier in the fight. Maximillian appeared on the skiff just as the smoke cleared and began battling with the four archers for control of the ship. Caena had obtained a potion of featherfall from one of the dead Emerald Claw soldiers and simply leaped off the side of the ship. Belowdeck, Sarge and Seth had also obtained potions of featherfall from the dead soldiers, and were cutting their way out of the wreckage of the ship. With the ship only a hundred feet above the ground, they broke free and lept through the firey tornado that was the elementals engaged in combat, and floated free of the wreckage. Meanwhile, Maximillian had defeated two of the four archers, but was finally taken down. The archers lowered the skiff and caught up to Caena, ordering him to surrender or they’d kill his friend. Caena complied and boarded the skiff. As the skiff descended towards the wreckage to search for survivors, Sarge and Seth set up an ambush. When the skiff landed, Sarge remained hidden, magically camouflaged by Seth’s magic. The ordered Seth to surrender, and Sarge burst from her hiding place and cut one of the archers down. Caena slew the other one with a spell. After healing Maximillian to consciousness, the party flew the wobbly skiff to Sterngate. There, they reported what happened to the gate guard and ordered them to let them in the city, displaying their papers given to them by the Dark Lanterns. They were let into the city, but the soldiers took the skiff to insepct it. They obtained an inn room. After discussion among the party members, they decided that the pursuit wasn’t worth the trouble for what they were getting paid. They decided to return to Sharn on the morrow, and request either additional reinforcements or assistance.

8 Barrakas: After a night’s rest at an inn, they returned to the makeshift impound at the local barracks, and found that the skiff would probably be impossible to repair. Discussing methods of travel, Seth was inclined towards buying horses and riding the thousand or more miles back to Sharn, but Maximillian suggested taking the Lightning rail. As a member of House Orien, and a dragonmarked heir of the House at that, he stated that he could get a discount. Seth agreed to this, as long as it wasn’t too expensive. Maximillian went and spoke at length with the House Orien ticket master, and was able to secure for them extremely discounted prices. The party boarded the train heading north to Starliskur and then west to Wroat and Sharn, unaware that Lucan and Grilsha were aboard the same train. Around three in the afternoon (they boarded the train at twelve), they reached Starliskur, but only entered the town in order to purchase a few scrolls, then returned to the lightning rail. As night began to fall, Caena and Maximillian visited the bar a car forward of the private cabin they had secured. Seth and Sarge remained in the cabin, with the door locked, when a knock came. Seth called out asking who it was, and received the reply “Mr Stellos, here to see you.” “What do you want?” Seth called back. “I believe you requested a meeting with me” was the answer. Seth opened the door and two average farmer-type looking men walked in and sat down. What was not immediately obvious was that the one doing the talking was not Lucan. The other one, who stayed silent, was Lucan, and he spoke by dominating the other man and telepathically instructing him on what to say. Seth and Lucan talked for a while, and Lucan explained (or rather stated in such a manner that Seth could make the assumptions) that he wasn’t acting of his own will, but that of the sword. Further, he hadn’t acted in his own will in stealing the sword, but on the orders of another. He could speak with Seth as long as he didn’t consider him a threat to his arrival in Karnath, but if he saw him as a threat, he would have to kill him. Seth asked Lucan if he would be willing to meet him again, and Lucan agreed, saying that he would contact him again. Then both of them stood and left. Seth and Sarge immediately went and informed Caena and Maximillian of what had just happened. Caena and Seth then began investigating the train, finding it odd that two farmers could afford passage on the lightning rail. They found a group of three farmers, and upon questioning, learned that there had been a forth, named Joe, who they hadn’t seen in an hour. After some back and forth questions of the passengers, they tracked Joe’s last seen appearance to a cabin a car back from their own. The door, however was locked. Seth called over a conductor, and convinced him that he thought his friend Joe might be hurt, since he was in the cabin and not responding. The conductor opened the door, and Joe was nowhere to be seen in the cabin. The curtains were drawn, but otherwise it appeared to be an empty cabin. Seth was apart to start a search of the compartments, but the conductor stopped him, finding him a bit suspicious. Seth then went outside and used his hand of the mage to open the windows and the compartments from outside the train, as well as unlocking the door to the cabin from the inside. Inside one of the compartments was an inky blackness that he couldn’t see into. What he did see, however, was bulky cloaked figures on horses riding up alongside the train, and Halflings on glidewings swooping out of the clouded night sky. Shouting “Raiders!” he ran back inside the train. He darted back into the cabin and searched the darkened area and found the cold corpse of Joe stuffed inside the compartment. Lucan and Grilsha emerged from a forward car as the four discussed this. Seth announced that he had a plan to free Lucian from the swords control. Lucan was forced to act under his orders to stop anyone from interfering with his trip to Karnath and stabbed Seth, nearly fatally. However, Seth stayed up and managed to cast Protection from Evil upon Lucan. They quickly persuaded Lucan to allow himself to be staked. Meanwhile, at the front of the train, the warforged raiders had boarded the train and killed the conductor for refusing to stop the train, which resulted in the loss of control of the elemental and was causing the lightning rail to begin an uncontrolled acceleration. Maximillian, Seth, and Caena ran towards the front of the train, while Sarge and Grilsha fought the band of warforged raiders who had been slaughtering their way towards the middle cars from the rear who were led by a warforged named Scimitar. Caena, Maximillian and Seth reached and engaged the warforged with only seconds to spare, and Seth and Caena were almost killed before Maximillian reached the lightning reins and was able to stop the lightning rail. A lucky blast from Caena finished off Bastard, the leader of the warforged raiders. With over half the passengers dead as well as the conductor, Maximillian piloted the lightning rail on the rest of it’s trip to Wroat.

9 Barrakas: The lightning rail arrives in Wroat early in the day. The party is questioned, and based primarily on Maximillian’s party is not detained. They transfer Lucan, hidden in a box, to another lightning rail, and head back to Sharn. Arriving late that evening, they bring the box containing Lucan to the Dark Lanterns and receive their reward. The party vows never to take a job like this one again.

10 Barrakas: Seth begins another crafting project, occupying him for several days, while the rest of the party simply enjoys the relaxation in Sharn. Maximillian reports to Naz’ghuul about the events of his mission.

14 Barrakas: After finishing his crafting work, the party begins looking for work again and finds a posting requesting skilled adventurers. No name is signed to the posting, but an address of inquiry leads them to the Medusa’s Kiss. As it turns out, it is indeed Demisi. She wishes them to seek out an ancient hobgoblin mask that is buried somewhere under the sewers. She provides directions to the sewer hatches, then sends the party on their way. The party descends into the sewers, and quickly finds themselves being stalked by kobolds. They ‘ambush’ the kobolds, capturing one named Yipyap. They enlist his help for a couple of silver coins, upon which he proceeds to ride on Sarge’s head. After some brief encounters with sewer monsters, they find a hatch leading down further under the city into the lava pools. Once in the caverns of the lava pools they managed to locate the ruins described by Demisi. They fought their way through the ruins and located the mask, only to find a small clutch of wrymling red dragons. They barely defeated the dragons, and retrieved the mask, as well as located the dragons horde, which composed mostly of a huge mass of copper coins. They decided to leave the copper there, taking only the silver, gold and platinum coins. As the party departed the ruins, they encountered an Empty vessel half dragon Inspired. She attacked the party, but was slain. On emerging back to the sewers, they directed Yipyap to bring his kobold friends and gifted them with the mass of copper coins they had left in the ruins. The kobolds enthusiastically rushed into the lava pools shouting with glee. Upon their return to the Medusa’s Kiss, they handed the mask over to Demisi, and she paid them as agreed.

15 Barrakas: Maximillian wakes up to find his dragonmark to have grown to cover most of his face. Seth grows tired of living in a curtained off area of the Clifftop adventurer’s hall barracks, and he and Sarge go real-estate hunting. They meet with a real-estate agent, who agrees to take them to lunch the next day when the rest of the party can attend.

16 Barrakas: The real estate agent treated the party to a meal at Sannid’s in the Platinum Heights of Upper Central. After the meal, he showed the party to the house, which was in the Highwater district of Upper Dura. It had a living room, a pantry with a cooking pit, a study room, two bedrooms, and a bathroom. The four of them, finding it to their satisfaction, agreed to purchase it, and moved there from Clifftop the same day. Seth immediately went back to work crafting magical items.

27 Barrakas: A gargoyle courier arrived from Lady Eladrin d’Cannith, requesting the parties urgent help, and for them to meet her at her house. When the party arrived, she was under attack by Karnathi zombies, which they put a rapid end to. Eladrin told them that the Emerald Claw had attacked her at her own house and stolen the schema’s and the creation pattern that they had recovered previously, as well a great deal of her notes on the location of the fourth schema. She begged them to quickly locate the fourth schema before the Emerald Claw gained it and completed the pattern. After some debate, the party accepted the task, primarily on the grounds that they didn’t want the Emerald Claw to have the pattern, but insisted on it’s destruction upon recovery. Eladrin hedged, avoiding answering that demand directly, and quickly gave them money for supplies. Unbeknownst to both the party and Eladrin, Merrix d’Cannith, Eladrin’s true employer, was observing events at the household all along, and intentionally had allowed the location of the schema to slip to the Emerald Claw. His plan is to let the Emerald Claw locate and retrieve the fourth schema, and then recover the completed pattern. She also sent them to meet with a gnome named Byam, the captain of an undersea ship (Submarine). They purchased supplies and headed down to the docks to meet him. He and his crew showed the party into a warehouse with a hollowed out bottom where the ship rested. Once the crew and party had embarked, Captain Byam set out towards Xen’drik where the fourth schema waited.

28 Barrakas: Sarge remained huddled midship away from the viewing room, playing cards with Seth. Caena and particularly Maximillian enjoyed the view from the viewing bubble as they moved through the Saigon’s teeth, taking a shortcut on their route to Xen’drik.

1 Rhaan: The submarine was attacked by a dire shark and it’s sahuagin handlers. The submarine quickly rises to the surface, but it caught in the nets of the sahuagin. The crew, Maximillian, and Caena emerge into the water with potions of water breathing in order to cut the nets. The dire shark eats the four gnomes who emerged to help cut the nets before Caena and Maximillian finish cutting the Sea Dart free. Caena creates a ring of blades around himself, which doesn’t stop the dire shark from swallowing him whole. Maximillian swims into the dire shark’s mouth after him, and uses his newly strengthened dragonmark to teleport himself and Caena back inside the ship. He manages to heal Caena enough to keep him from dying despite the whirling blades keeping everyone back from the Valenar elf. The ship rises to the surface, and Byam, the two surviving gnome crewmen, and the party defeat the sahuagin handlers, and, after making repairs, continue onto Xen’drik.

2 Rhaan: In the late afternoon, the Sea Dart arrives about a mile away from Stormreach. Byam tells the adventurers that he will wait for them for 30 days, then leave. The party makes it to Stormreach without incident and goes to the local House Cannith enclave to seek assistance in garnering transportation to make it to the ruins, which lay deeper into the jungles. There are two gnome secretaries, who display complete apathy to pretty much everything the party does, and the head of the local enclave, Miran d’Cannith. Miran is obstinate, barely displaying any concern with the parties mission. They manage to wrangle a letter of credit out of him for a riverboat to get to the ruins, but in the end, after they have the letter, they practically storm out of the room, knocking aside Miran’s pet project on the way, several floating geometric spheres. The party goes to the docks, and finds the riverboat mentioned in the letter of credit, a captain Chinxero’s boat, called the Marlow. Chinxero is reluctant to take the payment in the letter, citing his lack of trust that Miran will honor it. The party is sympathetic, and leaves. They then go to the House Orien enclave, and tell the local head, Banthen d’Orien, all about the schema, the patterns, and their mission. Banthen is quite pleased with the party, and the potential to gain an opportunity to blackmail House Cannith. He promises to provide them with at least one-way transportation to the vicinity of the ruins, via the next greater heir of Passage that becomes available. He anticipates that this should be no longer than three of four days. The party cheerfully agrees, and goes to find an inn. Once they get to an inn, however, they find an elven woman named Muroni waiting for them. She tells them it was destiny that they would meet here, and asks to accompany them and watch them. Seth adamantly refuses, though the rest of the party is receptive. She buys them inn rooms, which everyone but Seth (and therefore Sarge) accept.

6 Rhaan: The party attempts to teleport based on a vague description and a general “here” on the map. Appearing in the middle of the jungle, they decide to try again using the river as a landmark. The second attempt places them at the river successfully. The Orien heir stays with the party having expended his teleportation uses for the day.

7 Rhaan: The party reaches the temple, and the Orien heir returns to the enclave. The party enters the temple and kills numerous Emerald Claw soldiers. However, after a long forgotten trap left by the giants kills Seth, the rest of the party is eventually overwhelmed and perish.

25 Rhaan: The Lightbringer sages uncover mention of the Curse of the Decaying Raven in a truly ancient tome regarding the lands of Barovia in northern Karnath. The place was of little strategic importance and was able to remain untouched by the Last War. Attempts to recruit from the region were met with failure, no recruiting parties returned. Suspecting that Paladin Alexander, now in an advanced state of the wasting curse might need assistance, begins to prepare to dispatch forces to Barovia.

3 Sypheros: High Priest Renauld Flameborn, a well respected asamir priest in central Thrane is called to the Lightbringers headquarters in Flamekeep. He is told of the Paladin Alexander’s curse and his help is requested in breaking it. At the same time, three paladins including Ashlyn Forini are dispatched as an advance force to Barovia. High Priest Renauld sets out to the Lightbringers well concealed base in Karnath to meet up with Alexander.

17 Sypheros: The Lightbringers advance force arrives in Barovia. They learn that the region is ruled by Strahd, and other powerful creatures of the night. However, when they attempt to leave, the road becomes choked with mist and they are unable to find their way out.

24 Sypheros: Danovich’s son, Doru, is killed by werewolves. Danovich goes mad with grief, and begins to study the Liber Blaspheme which he had uncovered many years ago.

3 Aryth: Danovich raises his son Doru as a blaspheme. This act of evil irrevocably taints the priest with the corruption of the Liber and creates the beginning of the zombie plague. Strahd kills the burgomaster of Barovia, Kolyan, for ‘interfering with his plans.’ His grief stricken daughter Illyena mourns his passing, and lays his body in state in their home. His son, Ismark, becomes the nominal burgomaster in his father’s steed.

4 Aryth: The plague spreads throughout the town. Near the church where Doru, now a blaspheme, hunts casualties are high, but the three paladins manage to contain most of the zombies, evacuating as many of the townspeople as they can find to the center of town and building barricades.

14 Aryth: High Priest Renauld arrives at the Lightbringer stronghold in Karnath, and meets with Paladin Alexander, and Lars Ostren. The three travel in secret towards the borders of Barovia, as an Aundarian, a Flamite priest, and a Karnathian paladin together might attract unwanted attention.

18 Aryth: Lorsanna d’Medani, a least marked member of her house, receives a dream compelling her to travel to Barovia. She sees the faces of Alexander, Renauld, and Lars and feels compelled to help them.

19 Aryth: Lassar is given an assignment from a contact in the Karnathi military to investigate disappearances of multiple ‘recruiting’ squads in the region of Barovia and sets out from Atur.

24 Aryth: In the village of Barovia, Ashlyn’s companions, Thendrick and Mathilda grow tired of just waiting for help to arrive, and attempt to strike at the heart of the infection in the church. Both perish brutally and rise as zombies.

28 Aryth: The three Lightbringers arrive at an outside Barovia called Halfway to Home. They stop there for night, planning to ride on to the village of Barovia in the morning. While they are sitting at a table in the common room, discussing their strategies and pasts, a Vistani walks in and leaves them a letter from the burgomaster of Barovia, pleading with their help against ‘the howls of wolves.’

1 Vulk: The party arrives in the Barovian valley. The area is completely choked in mist. When they pass through the gate, it slams shut behind them, with a rather loud screeching sound. They fight their way through the center of town, rescuing two children, one of which had been bitten on their way in. Exhausted from fighting their way through so many zombies, they spent the night in the inn, planning to assault the church in the morning. Inside they encountered Ismark in a intoxicated state and the Arenal elf, Demisi, who was seeking the Tome of Strahd.

Inside, they encountered two dolghasts, but dispatched them easily enough. Following clues they found inside, they made their way through a long trapped hallway, and came into the main chamber of the temple. There they found a dolgaunt muttering angrily to himself in the language of Xoriat. Upon spotting them, he launched into an attack, but was slain by the two of them. They searched the main chamber and located some treasure sealed inside a secret passage, and then headed back towards the catfolk encampment.

As they made their way through the bog, a bloodmote swarm moved in a buzzing cloud towards them from across a river. However, recognizing the undead nature of the swarm, Lorsanna, Alexander, and Renauld unleashed a blast of positive energy to turn them back, and the swarm fled back into the swamp, but a moment later a shambling mound burst from beneath the water and attempted to strangle Alexander to death in it’s vines. Alexander fortunately freed himself and the shambling mound shortly perished. They used flying magic on Alexander’s horse in order to cross the river without further incident. Up ahead, they spotted the ruins of the swamp fane. As they approached, the Drowned Lady shambled forth, attempting to use her eye against first Alexander, then Ulrick, and finally Lorsanna, but found no fear in any of their hearts., and was thus unable to use her Evil Eye. Once they had dealt with a local pack of blood eels (large leach like creatures) and the Drowned Lady, they were able to inspect the Swamp Fane. They sensed the latent natural energy concentrated in the fane, but were more interested in the box they found at the base of the fane. Lars used his magic to open the box and inside lay the Holy Symbol of Ravenkind. As it was late in the afternoon by this time, they decided to rest there at the center of the swamp rather than risk traveling back to town in the dark through the swamp. Ulrick, however, fearing for the safety of the town decided to return on his own. Again, Lars called upon his magic and created a Leomund’s Secure Shelter. Inside they waited for nightfall, preparing to break Lars lycanthropic curse. However, back at the village, Thirteen of the twenty villagers who had been bitten also transformed into wolves. While Renauld and Lorsanna were able to break Lars of his curse, it was all Ashlyn and Ulrick could do to contain the bitten townsfolk. Seven of them escaped into the wood, while Ulrick and Ashlyn held back the children who had transformed. The party remained in their shelter until shortly before dawn of the next day.

5 Vulk: Around seven in the morning, Raphail, one of the vampire servants of Strahd coalesced out of the mists in the center of Barovia. By using the children as a shield, Raphail defeated both of them, slaying Ashlyn and leaving Ulrick unconscious on the ground, barely alive. He then ordered the children to watch the edge of town and gave them special greeting instructions for Paladin Alexander and High Priest Renauld.

As the party approached the town, the children ran out to greet them, delivering the message as they’d been instructed. “High priest Renauld! Sir Alexander! There’s a man in black armor waiting for you in the center of town, and he says you have to die!” and then launching themselves at the two. Lorsanna simply placed them into a deep slumber as they lept forward and they left the children slumbering peacefully as the party galloped towards the center of town. On their arrival, they saw Raphail sitting on the fountain, with Ashlyn and Ulrick lying at his feet. He stood and delivered the following speech “Ah, hello there. I’m glad you made it alright. I sent out some children to greet you, but they seem to have fallen asleep on the job. So hard to get good help around here, especially when paladins are attacking you without the slightest provocation.
